title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #452: Largest Interval with ω(n) > log log n**

Let ω(n) count distinct prime factors. What is the largest interval I ⊆ [x,2x] where ω(n) > log log n for all n ∈ I?

Known: |I| ≥ log x/(log log x)². Open: Can we achieve (log x)^k?

Status: OPEN
mathContext: Analytic number theory: prime factor distribution, Hardy-Ramanujan, Erdős-Kac.

title: omega ω(n)
content:
**omega n:** The count of distinct prime factors of n.

Examples:
- ω(1) = 0
- ω(6) = 2 (primes 2, 3)
- ω(30) = 3 (primes 2, 3, 5)

This is the "small omega" function, not counting multiplicity.

title: Satisfies Condition
content:
**satisfiesCondition n:** ω(n) > log log n.

By Erdős (1937), exactly half of all integers satisfy this.

For n = 30: ω(30) = 3 > log log 30 ≈ 1.22 ✓

title: Valid Interval
content:
**validInterval x a b:** An interval [a,b] ⊆ [x,2x] where ALL elements satisfy ω(n) > log log n.

**intervalLength a b:** The length b - a + 1.

The question: how long can such intervals be?

title: Hardy-Ramanujan Theorem
content:
**hardy_ramanujan:**

For almost all n: ω(n) ≈ log log n.

More precisely: |ω(n) - log log n| < ε · log log n for almost all n.

title: Erdős-Kac Theorem
content:
**erdos_kac_theorem:**

(ω(n) - log log n) / √(log log n) → Normal(0,1).

The number of prime factors has a Gaussian distribution!

title: Erdős 1937 Density
content:
**erdos_1937_density:**

The density of {n : ω(n) > log log n} is exactly 1/2.

This follows from Erdős-Kac: P(Normal > 0) = 1/2.

title: CRT Lower Bound
content:
**crt_lower_bound:**

There exist valid intervals with |I| ≥ (1+o(1)) · log x / (log log x)².

Construction: Find intervals where all elements are divisible by many small primes.

title: CRT Construction Idea
content:
**crt_construction_idea:**

If n is divisible by primorial P = 2·3·5·...·p, then ω(n) ≥ π(p).

Use CRT to find consecutive multiples of P in [x, 2x].

title: Maximum Valid Interval Length
content:
**maxValidIntervalLength x:** The maximum length of a valid interval in [x, 2x].

This is the central quantity the problem asks about.

title: Polynomial Length Conjecture
content:
**conjecture_polynomial_length:**

For any k, there exist valid intervals of length ≥ (log x)^k.

This is a major open conjecture—the gap between log x/(log log x)² and (log x)^k is huge.

title: Prime Gap Constraint
content:
**prime_gap_constraint:**

Primes p > 16 fail the condition: ω(p) = 1 < log log p.

So valid intervals in [x, 2x] must avoid all primes—they can only exist in prime gaps!

title: Primes Fail Condition
content:
**primes_fail_condition:**

For primes p > 16: ω(p) = 1 but log log p > 1.

Since e^e ≈ 15.15, primes above 16 have log log p > 1 > ω(p).

title: Primorial
content:
**primorial n:** The product of all primes ≤ n.

2# = 2, 3# = 6, 5# = 30, 7# = 210, ...

ω(n#) = π(n) = number of primes ≤ n.

title: Omega of Primorial
content:
**omega_primorial:**

ω(n#) = #{primes ≤ n} = π(n).

The primorial is the "most efficient" way to have many prime factors.

title: Small Examples
content:
**Examples of ω(n):**

- ω(1) = 0
- ω(2) = 1
- ω(6) = 2
- ω(30) = 3
- ω(210) = 4

These illustrate how ω grows with primorial divisibility.

title: Example: 30 Satisfies
content:
**example_30_satisfies:**

ω(30) = 3 > log log 30 ≈ 1.22.

So 30 satisfies the condition. It's divisible by 2, 3, and 5.

title: Consecutive Integers with Many Factors
content:
**consecutive_many_factors:**

For any k and L, there exist L consecutive integers each with ω ≥ k.

This is related to the CRT construction.

title: Big Omega Ω(n)
content:
**bigOmega n:** Count of prime factors WITH multiplicity.

Ω(12) = 3 (2²·3 = three factors)
ω(12) = 2 (only primes 2, 3)

Always ω(n) ≤ Ω(n).

title: Radical rad(n)
content:
**radical n:** Product of distinct prime factors.

rad(12) = 6, rad(18) = 6, rad(30) = 30.

ω(n) = ω(rad(n)) always.

title: Known Lower Bound
content:
**known_lower_bound:**

Valid intervals of length ≥ log x / (log log x)² exist.

This is established, but the question is: can we do much better?

title: Main Summary
content:
**erdos_452_summary:**

1. Density of {n : ω(n) > log log n} is 1/2 (Erdős 1937)
2. Valid intervals of length ≥ log x/(log log x)² exist (CRT)
3. Primes obstruct: no large prime in valid interval
4. Open: Can we achieve (log x)^k for any k?

title: Main Theorem
content:
**erdos_452:**

Erdős Problem #452 remains OPEN.

The exact growth rate of the maximum valid interval length is unknown.
